intro: Trifolium erythraeum, commonly known as the red clover, is a flowering plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its trifoliate leaves composed of three oval-shaped leaflets. The plant produces small, pink or white flowers that bloom in dense clusters, typically from late spring to early summer. Trifolium erythraeum is known for its ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen, making it an important plant in agricultural and ecological contexts. It is also used in traditional medicine and as a forage crop for livestock.
